cleanText:
Hello, Reggie. You were the band leader on the Late Late Show for eight years.

That's true.

Welcome back to Late Night.

Thank you. It's good to be back. It feels good.

Yeah. How does it... Do you miss the regularity, the day in, day out?

Um, America, you know? Uh, no. Uh, I... No, I mean, you know, it's funny. It's like it was like such... it's such a part of your life. It's like it's just the thing that's constant, and it also almost becomes so constant that you don't feel time at all. So then when it stops, it just takes a while to even get used to it not being around. It's crazy. But um, but when I come back, this is like another show that I've been on. Um, you know, similar kind of vibes, like it's so familiar to me. So it's actually very comforting.

Yeah. This feels... you're really casual right now.

Yeah. I mean, I... I mean, ish. I mean, I was definitely nervous to come on the show, cuz I... I regard this show very, very highly.

Why?

Because I'm paid to say that.

That's okay. Good. Okay. Yeah. I was going to say, then our finances are going to the right place.

Uh, you're a man of many talents, but you're on the road right now. You're doing standup, correct?

Yes.

Standup... maybe is... would you call it standup?

I mean, yeah. I mean, I... I call it like a comedy show.

Yes.

Comedy show.

You got to come up with better brands.

I know. It's like, "Come to my comedy show."

"Come to my comedy show." Take it. Take it.

There'll be comedy.

Well, you do a lot of different things on your show. It's... It's a lot of it is unscripted. You are discovering the moment. Correct.

Yeah. Yeah, for sure. I mean, you know, I... I improvise everything. Um, I usually just... My favorite is to like be having a really deep conversation with someone right before I'm supposed to go on, and then have someone go like, "You're supposed to be on right now." And then I'll be like, "Oh, right." And then walk on stage. There's... there's... there's something so funny to me personally about that, about it's like... Yeah. So anyways, yeah. So if you add a little mustard or whatever. Oh yeah, okay, cool. We go out there... like... like I don't know. I guess it just kind of puts me in a cool because I'm not thinking about the show.

And then suddenly, like, I come out and like, "Oh, here's... here's people. Here's a... here's my opportunity to communicate something or whatever," and then in the... and then I find what needs to happen in that moment. Do you find if you're having the opposite experience where you're talking to somebody and it's just a banal conversation, they're teetering on and on about uh, preschool applications for their little kid, that your show immediately sucks because you've been pulled into the vortex and the wormhole of of their uh, their inability to hold your attention?

Yes, there... there... there is that. That's really well articulated. I haven't heard that in... in a while, but you know, that's what drugs are for. So...

That's what it is. You got to leave that little space just in case you need to pop something. And you know, it's... I'm curious, you know, we live in strange times right now. I do a little bit of stuff on the road as well, and I... and I feel like the audiences are... are shifting somewhat. They seem like they want different things right now. Have you noticed that?

Yeah. Oh, 100%. Yeah. Um, you know, cuz my... my show... I mean, in the past, my shows were always goofy, abstract, you know, strange, but now I have these moments of sincerity, you know, that... that took me a while to get comfortable with. But I think in these times, uh, you know, comedy is really... and especially absurdity and comedy in general, but absurdity especially is so important for our minds because otherwise we just get... we just pile on this dread factor of like, "This isn't happening. This isn't going well. This doesn't look good. This is..." And um, and comedy zooms you out and gives you context. The fact that we're in this amazing world, this life that we're living, we're conscious beings. We can be helpful to one another. We can be loving to one another. We can overcome our fears. All of these things. And so giving us context by, you know, doing something really stupid... is... is... is like so... it feels good to me because you can feel the audience just go, "Yeah, you know, cuz I need it. We all need it." Because that's the reality. The majority of the reality is that... Yeah. the dread stuff or whatever is crucial and is happening and is affecting a lot of people, but mostly life is enjoying life and being a part of yourself, your journey of self-understanding.

You feel... do you feel the audience sort of needs that escape?

I think they absolutely need it. You need that room, otherwise you're just constantly... you know, you're just like wired and and like, "I don't know what's going on," and then you lose track of your community, and really community is the thing that keeps you in check, right? So comedy is a form of like rapid community because you're in an audience with all these other people, and when you laugh together, those are... that's what I like to call a moment of instantaneous enlightenment, you know?

We haven't had many of those here, I got to say. We're trying. We're trying.

Oh, you do... you do it well.

Well, you know what I do, but you... you do speak to... I do think when people ask about that, it is like laughter means you actually understand the same premise, and I... and if you at least recognize the same premise, and I do think you talk to people and it feels like you're living in totally different realities with other people, and so if are laughing at something, you see an absurdity that you see somewhere else. Yeah. But I... I've seen your Instagram though. You are... you're political on Instagram. You don't hold back on the things you talk about. I... I've seen your comedy live as well, and you go to absurd places, flights of fantasy. You... you can... you can tune that up and down. Have you felt a desire to infuse more politics or more of the authentic Reggie Watts into that absurdity, or do you worry about like taking people out of sort of the enjoyment of of what you bring to a space?

Yeah, I mean, it's been... it's been an interesting road. You know, I am unashamedly, you know, for the Palestinian cause and what's happening in Gaza right now. Um, yeah, without getting too emotional, but all that tempered with... uh, I have so many Jewish friends, and and oddly, I took a 23 and me, and I'm like, "Not that this means anything. I'm sure people be like, 'Hey, bring it to whatever.'" But... but I am like 13% Ashkanazi Jewish, and uh, and I didn't know where that came from, but then I re... realized my mom, um, uh, said our family comes from Poland, and that my great aunt went to concentration camp, and she survived it, thankfully. She was like, you know, skeletal and so forth when they found her, but she survived it, and I got to meet her. Um, but um, uh, so there is that in my family, and it's like, you know, I have always tried to be very, very clear, and especially with my Jewish friends. Hannah Einbinder is a huge friend of mine. Jews are not what Zionism is. It's... it's just not that. It's... it's just... it... it's just isn't. And... and I don't want anybody to... I don't want anybody... any lives to be lost. I think that humanity is so incredible. Like, we are so... we're creative, curious, problem-solving, collaborative uh, people. And I think everything else is like really just a handful of sociopaths that are trying to convince us that we're not that just because they want some resources in the material world, which is the most ridiculous I've ever heard of. And so, um, so because of that, so I am... and it's been hard, right? Cuz you say that and all a sudden you get attacked by all sides, all kinds of people. But I will say that the tide feels like it's turning, and this is about compassion and humanity and realizing that we are of each other and we are one family. I... I want the world to be better for the worst of us. I... I want it to be... I... I want the worst of us to go, "Oh, oh, oh, I up." You know, it's like... but you know, because that's to me, that's what life is about, especially this time. Like, so much is happening, like AI and quantum computing and fusion energy and psychedelics and and science being like, you know, like the... the web telescope looking at pictures of the universe and going like, "Oh, that doesn't match our models. Oh, we're going to have to rewrite our entire cosmology," or like discoveries and quantum consciousness, all this stuff that's happening at the same time that like the worst dark things are happening, the most incredible enlightening things are happening simultaneously. So, this is an interesting time.

What do you... What do you think about AI? I know a lot of people have fears about that, especially in the creative industry. Are you worried about it?

AI? Uh... nice.

Uh, yeah. No, I'm... I'm... I'm AI positive. I...

Are you... Well,

don't tell anybody. Um, I just got diagnosed. No, I...

um... No, I mean, I... I'm positive. I... I... I know a lot of like AI researchers, like PhD people that are working, and they're... they're fairly positive about it. Here's my... here's my theory. It's kind of like droplets of water. Yeah. Getting too close to each other.
